content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The slide contains multiple sections of tissue, which appear to be lymph nodes. I can identify at least five separate lymph node profiles of varying sizes, embedded in adipose tissue. Several of the larger nodes show extensive replacement by a dense, basophilic (purple) cell population, which is highly suspicious for metastatic carcinoma. My initial impression is that this is a lymph node dissection with a high likelihood of finding positive nodes.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I am systematically examining each lymph node on the slide. The zoom is on the periphery of the bottom-left lymph node. This is a critical area because metastatic cells often first arrive and implant in the subcapsular sinus, which is located just beneath the lymph node capsule. I am carefully inspecting the capsule and the surrounding perinodal fat for any evidence of isolated tumor cells or small metastatic deposits, as well as for potential extranodal extension (tumor breaking through the capsule). I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I would systematically examine each lymph node on the slide. This particular zoom is on the second lymph node from the top on the left. The zoomed area is located at the periphery of the lymph node, adjacent to the capsule and the subcapsular sinus. This is a critical area to inspect, as it is the most common initial site for metastatic cancer cells to deposit. The low-power view might have suggested an architectural disruption or a subtle color change in this specific location, prompting a higher-magnification look to confirm or exclude the presence of tumor cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am systematically evaluating each lymph node for evidence of metastasis. The green box is placed over one of the larger lymph nodes in the lower portion of the slide. This area is within the main body of the node, away from the fatty hilum or capsule. I am zooming in here to assess the overall architecture of the lymphoid tissue at higher power, specifically looking for any disruption of the normal nodal structure by foreign, atypical cell populations which would be suspicious for metastatic carcinoma. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my primary task for these sections is to identify any potential metastasis. I would systematically examine each lymph node. The zoom is placed on the fourth lymph node from the top (the largest one at the bottom). The specific area is near the periphery of the lymphoid parenchyma. This is a critical region to examine because metastatic carcinoma cells typically first lodge in the subcapsular sinus before invading the rest of the node. Therefore, I am zooming in to carefully scrutinize this area at high power for any small clusters of atypical cells (micrometastasis). I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I would systematically examine each lymph node on the slide. The green box is placed on the second major lymph node from the top. This specific area is of interest because it is located at the periphery of the lymphoid parenchyma, near the subcapsular sinus. This is a common location for the initial seeding of metastatic tumor cells. Furthermore, the interface between the dense lymphoid tissue and the adjacent perinodal fat/sinus needs careful evaluation for any signs of infiltration. The goal is to screen this high-yield area for any non-lymphoid, atypical cell clusters that might represent metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this area because it is located in the lymph node at the top right of the image, specifically at the periphery or subcapsular region. This is a common location for early metastatic deposits to arrive via the afferent lymphatic vessels. At low power, there is a subtle change in the texture and color in this region compared to the more uniform lymphoid tissue deeper in the node, raising suspicion for an infiltrate that requires high-power evaluation. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

This high-power view shows the edge of the lymph node tissue, the fibrous capsule, and adjacent adipose tissue. There are several clusters of small, dark cells floating in the white background space, detached from the main tissue. These have the appearance of lymphocytes and are likely an artifact of tissue processing known as "lymphocyte floaters" or carryover. Within the actual tissue section, I can see the capsule and a dense population of lymphocytes. In this specific field, there are no definitive features of metastatic carcinoma, such as atypical glands or large, pleomorphic epithelial cells. My impression is that this particular area shows processing artifact, and I would continue to examine the entire periphery of this node and all other nodes to rule out metastasis.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see the dense, dark-staining population of normal lymphocytes. However, infiltrating the subcapsular and cortical sinusoids are clusters and nests of atypical epithelial cells. These cells are larger than the surrounding lymphocytes, have more abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm, and large, pleomorphic, and hyperchromatic nuclei. They are forming back-to-back, poorly-formed glandular structures. This morphology is characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic colorectal carcinoma.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see a dense and polymorphous population of lymphoid cells, consistent with a lymph node. There are features of reactive hyperplasia, including the presence of lymphoid follicles, some with pale germinal centers. A prominent hyalinized blood vessel is visible on the left side of the field. Crucially, I do not see any discrete nests, clusters, or glands formed by atypical epithelial cells. The cellular population appears to be entirely composed of lymphocytes, plasma cells, and histiocytes. Therefore, my impression of this specific field is that it represents a reactive lymph node, and it is negative for metastatic carcinoma.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows dense lymphoid tissue. There are several recognizable lymphoid follicles with germinal centers, which appear as paler, rounded aggregates of larger lymphocytes. The surrounding tissue is composed of a dense population of small, mature lymphocytes. I do not see any nests, glands, or single files of atypical epithelial cells with pleomorphic nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm, which would be indicative of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression of this area is reactive follicular hyperplasia, consistent with a benign, reactive lymph node. There is no evidence of malignancy in this field of view.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I see a dense and diffuse proliferation of small, round, blue cells with scant cytoplasm, which are morphologically consistent with lymphocytes. The architecture is that of lymph node parenchyma. At the upper right corner, there is perinodal adipose tissue and some greenish-black pigment, which is likely tattoo ink used to mark the specimen during surgery or grossing. I do not see any definite evidence of metastatic carcinoma in this field. There are no atypical glands, nests of large epithelial cells with pleomorphic nuclei, or significant desmoplastic reaction. My impression of this specific area is that it represents benign/reactive lymphoid tissue, negative for malignancy.
This is ROI 6 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see a dense infiltrate of small, dark, round cells, which are lymphocytes, characteristic of a lymph node. However, infiltrating this lymphoid stroma, particularly towards the top and left, are clusters and sheets of larger, atypical cells. These cells have more abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm, larger and more irregular nuclei, and are arranged in a disorganized fashion, contrasting sharply with the surrounding lymphocytes. My impression is that these are malignant epithelial cells, consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma. Therefore, this is a positive lymph node.
